metadata.subject: biology
metadata.dotPoint: The general structure of the biochemical pathways in photosynthesis and cellular respiration from initial reactant to final product

concepts.name: metabolism definition
concepts.formula: Metabolism is the totality of enzyme-catalysed reactions that occur within a living organism to maintain life
concepts.correct: Correct! Metabolism encompasses all the chemical reactions in an organism, each catalysed by specific enzymes, working together to sustain life processes.

wrong.error: You confused metabolism with just energy production. Metabolism includes ALL cellular reactions, not just ATP synthesis.
wrong.fix: Metabolism = all enzyme-catalysed reactions (building AND breaking down molecules). Energy production is just one part.
wrong.action: Think of metabolism as everything the cell does chemically: making proteins, breaking down food, copying DNA—all of it.

wrong.error: You thought metabolism only refers to breaking things down. It includes both building up and breaking down.
wrong.fix: Metabolism has two branches: anabolism (building) and catabolism (breaking down). Both are essential.
wrong.action: When people say 'fast metabolism' they usually mean catabolism, but true metabolism includes synthesis too.

wrong.error: You confused metabolism with a single reaction. Metabolism refers to chains and cycles of many sequential reactions.
wrong.fix: Metabolic pathways are sequences of reactions, each controlled by a different enzyme, allowing precise regulation.
wrong.action: Think of metabolism as a factory assembly line—many steps, many enzymes, all coordinated.

persistent.gap: You're not recognising metabolism as the complete set of an organism's chemical reactions.
persistent.action: List 5 different metabolic processes: protein synthesis, cellular respiration, DNA replication, photosynthesis, digestion.

concepts.name: anabolic reactions
concepts.formula: Anabolic reactions build complex molecules from simpler subunits, typically via condensation reactions that release water
concepts.correct: Correct! Anabolism is the constructive branch of metabolism—small molecules are joined together to form larger, more complex molecules through condensation reactions.

wrong.error: You confused anabolic with catabolic. Anabolic = building up; catabolic = breaking down.
wrong.fix: Anabolic = 'building' (think anabolic steroids build muscle). Catabolic = 'catastrophe/breaking down'.
wrong.action: Memory trick: ANA-bolic = 'ANA-ssemble' (put together). CATA-bolic = 'CATA-strophe' (break apart).

wrong.error: You thought anabolic reactions use water. They RELEASE water (condensation). Catabolic reactions USE water (hydrolysis).
wrong.fix: Condensation = joining molecules, water released. Hydrolysis = splitting molecules, water consumed.
wrong.action: Building a peptide bond? Water comes OUT. Breaking a peptide bond? Water goes IN.

wrong.error: You confused anabolic reactions with energy-releasing reactions. Anabolic reactions typically REQUIRE energy input.
wrong.fix: Anabolic reactions are usually endergonic (need energy). Building complex molecules requires ATP investment.
wrong.action: Building things takes effort (energy). Breaking things releases energy. Anabolism needs ATP; catabolism often makes ATP.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting anabolism with building/synthesis and condensation reactions.
persistent.action: Write the general equation: small molecules + energy → large molecule + water (condensation/anabolism).

concepts.name: catabolic reactions
concepts.formula: Catabolic reactions break down complex molecules into simpler components, typically via hydrolysis reactions that consume water
concepts.correct: Correct! Catabolism is the destructive branch of metabolism—large molecules are broken into smaller units through hydrolysis reactions, often releasing energy.

wrong.error: You confused catabolic with anabolic. Catabolic = breaking down; anabolic = building up.
wrong.fix: Catabolic reactions break bonds and release subunits. Think 'catastrophe' = destruction.
wrong.action: Digestion is catabolic—you break food down. Muscle building is anabolic—you build protein up.

wrong.error: You thought catabolic reactions release water. They CONSUME water (hydrolysis). Anabolic reactions RELEASE water.
wrong.fix: Hydrolysis = 'water splitting'—water is USED to break bonds. The -OH and -H from water attach to the fragments.
wrong.action: Hydro-lysis = water-splitting. The water molecule is split and used to break the bond.

wrong.error: You thought all catabolic reactions produce ATP. They release energy, but not always as ATP directly.
wrong.fix: Catabolic reactions release energy stored in bonds. This energy may be captured as ATP, heat, or transferred to carriers.
wrong.action: Breaking glucose releases energy → some becomes ATP, some becomes heat, some loads hydrogen carriers.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting catabolism with breakdown/digestion and hydrolysis reactions.
persistent.action: Write the general equation: large molecule + water → small molecules + energy (hydrolysis/catabolism).

concepts.name: condensation reactions
concepts.formula: Condensation reactions join monomers by removing water, forming polymers with covalent bonds
concepts.correct: Correct! In condensation (dehydration synthesis), monomers are joined when a hydroxyl (-OH) from one and hydrogen (-H) from another are removed, forming water and a covalent bond.

wrong.error: You confused condensation with hydrolysis. Condensation removes water to join; hydrolysis adds water to split.
wrong.fix: Condensation = water exits (con-DENSE = squeeze water out). Hydrolysis = water enters (hydro = water, lysis = splitting).
wrong.action: Joining amino acids? Water leaves. Breaking peptide bonds? Water enters. Opposite reactions.

wrong.error: You thought condensation breaks bonds. Condensation FORMS bonds by removing water.
wrong.fix: Condensation is a building reaction: two molecules join, losing H2O. The new bond replaces the lost atoms.
wrong.action: Picture it: -OH from one molecule + -H from another = H2O released, and the molecules are now bonded.

wrong.error: You confused the products. Condensation produces a larger molecule plus water, not smaller molecules.
wrong.fix: Condensation: small + small → big + water. Hydrolysis: big + water → small + small.
wrong.action: Condensation builds UP (makes bigger molecules). The water is a byproduct of joining.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding that condensation joins molecules by removing water.
persistent.action: Draw two amino acids joining: show the -OH and -H that leave as water, and the peptide bond that forms.

concepts.name: hydrolysis reactions
concepts.formula: Hydrolysis reactions break polymers into monomers by adding water across covalent bonds
concepts.correct: Correct! Hydrolysis uses water to break covalent bonds—the -OH attaches to one fragment and the -H to the other, regenerating the original monomers.

wrong.error: You confused hydrolysis with condensation. Hydrolysis uses water to break bonds; condensation releases water to form bonds.
wrong.fix: Hydrolysis = hydro (water) + lysis (breaking). Water is the tool that breaks the bond.
wrong.action: Hydrolysis is the reverse of condensation. What was joined can be split by adding water back.

wrong.error: You thought hydrolysis releases water. Hydrolysis CONSUMES water to break bonds.
wrong.fix: The water molecule is split: -OH goes to one fragment, -H goes to the other. Water is used up, not produced.
wrong.action: Digesting a protein? Each peptide bond broken needs one water molecule to be consumed.

wrong.error: You thought hydrolysis requires energy input. Hydrolysis typically releases energy (exergonic).
wrong.fix: Breaking bonds in polymers often releases energy because the products are more stable than the reactants.
wrong.action: Digestion (hydrolysis) releases energy from food. That's why we eat—to break down molecules for energy.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding that hydrolysis uses water to break bonds.
persistent.action: Draw a dipeptide being hydrolysed: show water being added, the peptide bond breaking, and two amino acids forming.

concepts.name: photosynthesis overview
concepts.formula: Photosynthesis is anabolic—it uses light energy to build glucose from carbon dioxide and water, releasing oxygen
concepts.correct: Correct! Photosynthesis is an anabolic process that converts light energy into chemical energy stored in glucose, using CO2 and H2O as inputs and producing O2 as a byproduct.

wrong.error: You confused photosynthesis with respiration. Photosynthesis builds glucose; respiration breaks it down.
wrong.fix: Photosynthesis: CO2 + H2O + light → glucose + O2 (building). Respiration: glucose + O2 → CO2 + H2O + ATP (breaking).
wrong.action: Photosynthesis stores energy in glucose. Respiration releases that energy as ATP.

wrong.error: You thought photosynthesis is catabolic. It's anabolic—it builds complex organic molecules from simple inorganic ones.
wrong.fix: Photosynthesis takes small molecules (CO2, H2O) and builds a large one (glucose). That's anabolism.
wrong.action: Photo = light, synthesis = building. Photosynthesis = using light to BUILD glucose.

wrong.error: You confused the waste product. Photosynthesis releases oxygen, not carbon dioxide.
wrong.fix: Oxygen comes from splitting water (photolysis). The oxygen we breathe is a 'waste product' of photosynthesis.
wrong.action: Photosynthesis: O2 out, CO2 in. Respiration: CO2 out, O2 in. Opposite gas exchange.

persistent.gap: You're not recognising photosynthesis as an anabolic, glucose-building process.
persistent.action: Write the photosynthesis equation: 6CO2 + 6H2O + light → C6H12O6 + 6O2. Identify inputs, outputs, energy source.

concepts.name: cellular respiration overview
concepts.formula: Cellular respiration is catabolic—it breaks down glucose using oxygen to release energy as ATP, producing carbon dioxide and water
concepts.correct: Correct! Cellular respiration is a catabolic process that breaks the bonds in glucose, using oxygen as the final electron acceptor, to produce ATP, CO2, and H2O.

wrong.error: You confused respiration with photosynthesis. Respiration breaks down glucose; photosynthesis builds it.
wrong.fix: Respiration: glucose + O2 → CO2 + H2O + ATP. It's the reverse of photosynthesis in terms of inputs and outputs.
wrong.action: Respiration releases the energy that photosynthesis stored. They're complementary opposites.

wrong.error: You thought cellular respiration is the same as breathing. Breathing is gas exchange; respiration is cellular energy production.
wrong.fix: Breathing = moving gases in/out of lungs. Cellular respiration = breaking down glucose in cells to make ATP.
wrong.action: You breathe to get O2 for respiration and remove CO2 produced by respiration. Different processes, linked by gas exchange.

wrong.error: You thought respiration only occurs in animals. All living cells (plant, animal, bacteria) perform cellular respiration.
wrong.fix: Plants photosynthesise AND respire. They make glucose in light, then break it down for ATP around the clock.
wrong.action: Plants respire 24/7. They photosynthesise only in light. At night, plants only respire.

persistent.gap: You're not recognising cellular respiration as a catabolic, energy-releasing process.
persistent.action: Write the respiration equation: C6H12O6 + 6O2 → 6CO2 + 6H2O + ATP. Compare with photosynthesis equation.

concepts.name: complementary pathways
concepts.formula: Photosynthesis and cellular respiration are complementary—the outputs of one are the inputs of the other
concepts.correct: Correct! These pathways form a cycle: photosynthesis produces glucose and oxygen, which respiration consumes to produce carbon dioxide and water, which photosynthesis uses.

wrong.error: You thought these pathways are independent. They're directly linked—products of one become reactants of the other.
wrong.fix: Photosynthesis outputs (glucose, O2) = respiration inputs. Respiration outputs (CO2, H2O) = photosynthesis inputs.
wrong.action: Draw a cycle: CO2 + H2O → photosynthesis → glucose + O2 → respiration → CO2 + H2O → repeat.

wrong.error: You thought only plants use both pathways. Many organisms use respiration; only autotrophs also photosynthesise.
wrong.fix: Heterotrophs (animals, fungi) only respire—they depend on autotrophs for glucose. Autotrophs do both.
wrong.action: Autotrophs make their own food (photo). Heterotrophs eat food (respire only). The cycle links them.

wrong.error: You thought the pathways cancel out. They don't—photosynthesis stores energy; respiration releases it when needed.
wrong.fix: Photosynthesis captures and stores light energy. Respiration releases that stored energy on demand. Different purposes.
wrong.action: Photosynthesis = charging a battery (storing energy). Respiration = using the battery (releasing energy).

persistent.gap: You're not seeing how photosynthesis and respiration form a complementary cycle.
persistent.action: Draw a diagram showing the cycle of matter and energy between photosynthesis and respiration.
